content.question: NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION. Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit. Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point. Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number. The graph of the continuous function <math alttext="g"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is shown above for <math alttext="negative 3 less than or equal to x, less than or equal to 5"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow><mo>≤</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. The function <math alttext="g"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is twice differentiable except at <math alttext="x equals 1"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Let <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> be the function with <math alttext="f of 1, equals 3 "><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and derivative given by <math alttext="f prime of x equals, open parenthesis, 6 times x squared, minus 5 x, close parenthesis, times e to the x power"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>6</mn><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>5</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><msup><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>. (a) Find the <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-coordinate of each critical point of <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. Classify each critical point as the location of a relative minimum, a relative maximum, or neither. Justify your answers.

frqParts.text: NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION. Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit. Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point. Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number. The graph of the continuous function <math alttext="g"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is shown above for <math alttext="negative 3 less than or equal to x, less than or equal to 5"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow><mo>≤</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. The function <math alttext="g"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is twice differentiable except at <math alttext="x equals 1"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Let <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> be the function with <math alttext="f of 1, equals 3 "><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and derivative given by <math alttext="f prime of x equals, open parenthesis, 6 times x squared, minus 5 x, close parenthesis, times e to the x power"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>6</mn><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>5</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><msup><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>. (a) Find the <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-coordinate of each critical point of <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. Classify each critical point as the location of a relative minimum, a relative maximum, or neither. Justify your answers.

(b) Find all values of <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> at which the graph of <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> has a point of inflection. Give reasons for your answers.

Fill in the missing entries in the table below to describe the behavior of <math alttext="g prime " overflow="scroll"><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></math> and <math alttext="g double prime " overflow="scroll"><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>″</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></math> on the interval <math alttext="negative 3 less than or equal to x, less than or equal to 5" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow><mo>≤</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Indicate Positive or Negative. Give reasons for your answers.

(d) Let <math alttext="h"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> be the function defined by <math alttext="h of x equals, f of x, times, g of x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Is <math alttext="h"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> increasing or decreasing on the interval <math alttext="1 less than x, less than 5"><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo><</mo><mi>x</mi><mo><</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow></math> ? Give a reason for your answer.

topic.text: 5.3: Determining Intervals on Which a Function Is Increasing or Decreasing

skill.text: Skill 2.D: Identify how mathematical characteristics or properties of functions are related in different representations.
